section.title: Collection Classes
section.para: A Collection is an object that contains a number of items, which can be any objects. Every item stored in a Collection has an associated index that you can use to retrieve the item from the collection with the at or [] methods.
Each Collection defines its own acceptable index types. Rexx provides the following Collection classes:

listitem.para: A sequenced collection of objects ordered by whole-number indexes.
A collection where the index and the item are the same object. Bag indexes can be any object and each index can appear more than once.

The CircularQueue class allows for storing objects in a circular queue of a predefined size. Once the end of the queue has been reached, new item objects are inserted from the beginning, replacing earlier entries. The collected objects can be processed in FIFO (first-in, first-out) or in a stack-like LIFO (last-in, first-out) order.
A collection with character string indexes. Index comparisons are performed using the string == comparison method.

A collection with indexes that can be any object. The IdentityTable class determines index item matches by using an object identity comparison. With object identity matches, an index will only match the same object instance. An identity table contains no duplicate indexes.

A sequenced collection that lets you add new items at any position in the sequence. A list generates and returns an index value for each item placed in the list. The returned index remains valid until the item is removed from the list.
A collection with character string indexes and values. Properties collections include support for saving and loading from disk files.

A sequenced collection with the items ordered as a queue. You can remove items from the head of the queue and add items at either its tail or its head. Queues index the items with whole-number indexes, in the order in which the items would be removed. The current head of the queue has index 1, the item after the head item has index 2, up to the number of items in the queue.
A collection with indexes that can be any object. A relation can contain duplicate indexes.
A collection where the index and the item are the same object. Set indexes can be any object and each index is unique.
A collection with character string indexes constructed from one or more string segments. Index comparisons are performed using the string == comparison method.
A collection with character string indexes. Index comparisons are performed using the string == comparison method.
A collection with indexes that can be any object. A table contains no duplicate indexes.

section.title: Organization of the Collection Classes
section.para: The following shows the logical organization of the Collection Classes. This does not represent the order that methods are inherited but rather the organization of the classes.

listitem.para: classes
classes
classes

section.title: Collection Class
section.para: The Collection class is a MIXIN class that defines the basic set of methods implemented by all Collections. Many of the Collection class methods are abstract and must be implemented by the inheriting subclasses.

section.title: [] (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the item associated with the specified index or indexes. If the collection has no item associated with the specified index or indexes, this method returns &nil;. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by a subclasses.

section.title: []= (Abstract Method)
section.para: Add an item to the collection at the specified index. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by subclasses.

section.title: allIndexes (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns an array of all indexes used by this collection. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by subclasses.

section.title: allItems (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns an array containing all items stored in the collection. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by subclasses.

section.title: at (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the item associated with the specified index or indexes. If the collection has no item associated with the specified index or indexes, this method returns &nil;. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by subclasses.

section.title: difference
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing only those items from the receiver whose indexes the argument collection does not contain. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: disjoint
section.para: Returns &true; if the receiver collection and argument collection do not have any items in common. &false; otherwise. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: equivalent
section.para: Returns &true; if all indexes in the receiver collection are also contained in the argument collection and both collections contain the same number of items; returns &false; otherwise. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the array contains an item associated with the specified index or indexes. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the collection contains the specified item at any index location. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: index (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the index associated with item. If item occurs more than once in the collection, the returned index value is undetermined. This is an abstract method which must be implemented by a subclass of this class.

section.title: intersection
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing only those items from the receiver whose indexes are in both the receiver collection and the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of items in the collection.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; with the same number of items as the receiver object. Any index with no associated item is omitted from the new array. Items in the new array will have the same order as the source array.

section.title: put (Abstract Method)
section.para: Add an item to the collection at the specified index. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by a subclass of this class.

section.title: subset
section.para: Returns &true; if all indexes in the receiver collection are also contained in the argument collection; returns &false; otherwise. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the collection. The supplier allows you to enumerate through the index/item pairs for the collection. The supplier is created from a snapshot of the collection and is unaffected by subsequent changes to the collection's contents.

section.title: union
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all the items from the receiver collection and selected items from the argument collection. This method includes an item from argument in the new collection only if there is no item with the same associated index in the receiver collection and the method has not already included an item with the same index. The order in which this method selects items in argument is unspecified (the program should not rely on any order). The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: xor
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all items from the receiver collection and the argument collection; all indexes that appear in both collections are removed. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The argument must also allow all of the index values in the receiver collection.

section.title: MapCollection Class
section.para: The MapCollection class is a MIXIN class that defines the basic set of methods implemented by all collections that create a mapping from an index object to a value.
This class is defined as a MIXIN class. The following classes inherit from MapCollection: , , , , , , , and SetCollection classes and .

section.title: &added50;of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created MapCollection object containing the specified index/item pairs. Each pair must be a &singledimarray; with exactly two items: the index as the first Array item, and the value as the second item. The pairs are processed left-to-right and added to the MapCollection object.

example.title: MapCollection class — of method
example.programlisting:
iso639 = .Directory~of(.Array~of("de", "Deutsch"), .Array~of("en", "English"), .Array~of("fr", "français")) say iso639~allIndexes~makeString(, ", ") -- de, en, fr say iso639~allItems~makeString(, ", ") -- Deutsch, English, français
-- using array notation iso639 = .Directory~of(("de", "Deutsch"), ("en", "English"), ("fr", "français"))

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; of the index values used by the receiver object. The index objects will not be ordered in any predictable order.

section.title: putAll
section.para: Returns the receiving collection with all items in collection added to it. The collection argument can be any object that supports a supplier method. Items from collection are added using the index values returned by the supplier. The item indexes from the source collection must be strings. The items are added in the order provided by the supplier object. If duplicate indexes exist in collection, the last item provided by the supplier will overwrite previous items with the same index.

section.title: OrderedCollection Class
section.para: The OrderedCollection class is a MIXIN class that defines the basic set of methods implemented by all collections that have an inherent index ordering.
This class is defined as a MIXIN class. The following classes inherit from OrderedCollection: , , , and .

section.title: append (Abstract Method)
section.para: Append an item to the end of the collection ordering. This is an abstract method that must be implemented by a subclass of this class.

section.title: appendAll
section.para: Returns the receiving collection with all items in collection appended to the end of it. The collection may be any object that implements an allItems method.

section.title: delete (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns and deletes the member item with the specified index from the collection. If there is no item with the specified index, &nil; is returned and no item is deleted. All elements following the deleted item will be moved up in the collection ordering and the size of the collection will be reduced by one element. Depending on the nature of the collection, the indexes of the moved items may be modified by the deletion.

section.title: difference
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing only those items from the receiver that are not also contained in the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: first (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the index of the first item in the collection order. Returns &nil; if the collection is empty.

section.title: firstItem (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the first item in the collection order. Returns &nil; if the collection is empty.

section.title: insert (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns a collection-supplied index for item item, which is added to the collection. The inserted item follows an existing item with index index in the collection ordering. If index is &nil;, item becomes the first item in the ordered collection. If you omit index, the item becomes the last item in the collection.

Inserting an item in the collection at position index will cause the items in the collection after position index to have their relative positions shifted by the collection object. Depending on the nature of the collection, the index values for any items already in the collection may be modified by the insertion.
This is an abstract method that must be implemented by a subclass of this class.

section.title: intersection
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing only those items from the receiver that are in both the receiver collection and the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: last (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the index of the last item in the collection order. Returns &nil; if the collection is empty.

section.title: lastItem (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the first item in the collection order. Returns &nil; if the collection is empty.

section.title: next (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the index of the item that follows the collection item having index index or returns &nil; if the item having that index is last in the collection.

section.title: previous (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns the index of the item that precedes the collection item having index index or returns &nil; if the item having that index is first in the collection.

section.title: section (Abstract Method)
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing selected items from the receiver. The first item in the new collection is the item corresponding to index start in the receiver. Subsequent items in the new collection correspond to those in the receiver, in the same sequence. If you specify the whole number items, the new collection contains only this number of items (or the number of subsequent items in the receiver, if this is less than items). If you do not specify items, the new collection contains all subsequent items of the receiver. The receiver remains unchanged.

section.title: sort
section.para: Sorts the collection of Comparable items into ascending order using an algorithm that is not guaranteed to be stable, and returns the sorted collection. See for details.

section.title: sortWith
section.para: Sorts the collection of items into ascending order using an algorithm that is not guaranteed to be stable, and returns the sorted collection. Ordering of elements is determined using the comparator argument. See for details.

section.title: stableSort
section.para: Sorts the collection of Comparable items into ascending order using a stable Mergesort algorithm, and returns the sorted collection. See for details.

section.title: stableSortWith
section.para: Sorts the collection of items into ascending order using a stable Mergesort algorithm, and returns the sorted collection. Ordering of elements is determined using the comparator argument. See for details.

section.title: subset
section.para: Returns &true; if all items in the receiver collection are also contained in the argument collection; returns &false; otherwise. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: union
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all the items from the receiver collection and selected items from the argument collection. This method includes an item from argument in the new collection only if there is no equivalent item in the receiver collection and the method has not already included. The order in which this method selects items in argument is unspecified (the program should not rely on any order). The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: xor
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all items from the receiver collection and the argument collection; all items that appear in both collections are removed. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: SetCollection Class
section.para:
This is a tagging MIXIN class only and does not define any methods of its own. Collections that implement SetCollection are
that constrain the index and item to be be the same object.
This class is defined as a MIXIN class. The following classes inherit from SetCollection: and .

section.title: Array Class
section.para: An Array is a possibly sparse collection with indexes that are positive whole numbers. You can reference Array items by using one or more indexes. The number of indexes is the same as the number of dimensions of the Array. This number is called the dimensionality of the Array.
Array items can be any valid Rexx object.

Array objects are variable-sized. The dimensionality of an array is fixed, but the size of each dimension is variable. When you create an array, you can specify a hint about how many elements you expect to put into the array or the array's dimensionality. However, you do not need to specify a size or dimensionality of an array when you are creating it. You can use any whole-number indexes to reference items in an array.

For any array method that takes an index, the index may be specified as either individual arguments or as an array of indexes. For example, the following are equivalent:
Array class — [] method
x = myarray[1,2,3] -- retrieves an item from a &multidimarray; index = .array~of(1,2,3) -- create an index list x = myarray[index] -- also retrieves from "1,2,3"
Methods such as that return index items will return a single numeric value for &singledimarray;s and an array of indexes for &multidimarray;s.

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new empty array. If you specify any size arguments, the size is taken as a hint about how big each dimension should be. The Array class uses this only to allocate the initial array object. For &multidimarray;s, you can also specify how much space is to be allocated initially for each dimension of the array.

Each size argument must a non-negative whole number. If it is 0, the corresponding dimension is initially empty. The dimensions may also be specified with one &singledimarray; of sizes. examples of method
Array class — of method
a = .array~new() -- create a new, empty array a = .array~new(3,3) -- create a new 3x3 array sizes = .array~of(4,4,4) a = .array~new(sizes) -- create new 4x4x4 array

section.title: of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created &singledimarray; containing the specified item objects. The first item has index 1, the second has index 2, and so on.

If you use the of method and omit any argument items, the returned array does not include the indexes corresponding to the omitted arguments. examples of method
Array class — of method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "David")
do name over a say name -- displays "Fred", "Mike", and "David" end
Returns the same value as the method.
Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes.
This method is the same as the method.
Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para:
Returns an array of all index positions in the array containing items. For &multidimarray;s, each returned index will be an array of index values. examples allIndexes method
Array class — allIndexes method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "David")
do name over a~allIndexes say name -- displays "1", "2", and "3" end
a~remove(2) -- remove second item
do name over a~allIndexes say name -- displays "1" and "3" end

section.title: allItems
section.para:
Returns an array of all items contained in the array. examples allItems method
Array class — allItems method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "David")
do name over a~allItems say name -- displays "Fred", "Mike", and "David" end
a~remove(2) -- remove second item
do name over a~allItems say name -- displays "Fred" and "David" end

section.title: append
section.para:
Appends an item to the array after the last item (the item with the highest index). The return value is the index of newly added item. The append method is only valid with &singledimarray;s. examples append method
Array class — append method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick") a~append("Fred") -- a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred")

section.title: at
section.para: Returns the item associated with the specified index or indexes. If the array has no item associated with the specified index or indexes, this method returns &nil;.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples at method
Array class — at method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick") say a~at(2) -- says: "Rick"

section.title: delete
section.para: Returns and deletes the member item with the specified index from the array. If there is no item with the specified index, &nil; is returned and no item is deleted. All elements following the deleted item will be moved up in the array ordering and the item indexes will be adjusted for the deletion. The size of the array will be reduced by one element.

The delete method is only valid with &singledimarray;s. The index argument may also be specified as an array of a single index. examples delete method
Array class — delete method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "Rick", "David") a~delete(2) -- removes "Mike", resulting in the array -- ("Fred", "Rick", "David")

section.title: dimension
section.para:
Returns the current size (upper bound) of dimension n (a positive whole number). If you omit n, this method returns the dimensionality (number of dimensions) of the array. If the number of dimensions has not been determined, 0 is returned. examples dimension method
Array class — dimension method
a = .array~of(,"Mike", "Rick") say a~dimension -- says: 1 (number of dimensions in the array) say a~dimension(1) -- says: 3 (upper bound of dimension one)
a = .array~new~~put("Mike",1,1)~~put("Rick",1,2) say a~dimension -- says: 2 (number of dimensions in the array) say a~dimension(1) -- says: 1 (upper bound of dimension one) say a~dimension(2) -- says: 2 (upper bound of dimension two)

section.title: dimensions
section.para: Returns an array containing each of the array dimension sizes. A &singledimarray; will return an array with a single size element.

section.title: empty
section.para:
Returns the receiving Array with all items removed. examples empty method
Array class — empty method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred", "Rick") a~empty -- a~items now returns "0"

section.title: fill
section.para:
Returns the receiving Array with all index locations set to value. examples fill method
Array class — fill method
a = .array~new(3,3) a~fill(0) -- initialize the matrix to all zeroes.

section.title: first
section.para:
Returns the index of the first item in the array or &nil; if the array is empty. For &multidimarray;s, the index is returned as an array of index values. examples first method
Array class — first method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred", "Rick") say a~first -- says: 1 a = .array~of(,"Mike", "Rick") say a~first -- says: 2

section.title: firstItem
section.para:
Returns the first item in the array or &nil; if the array is empty.
Array class — firstItem method
musketeers=.array~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis"") /* Creates array MUSKETEERS */ item=musketeers~firstItem /* Gives first item in array */ /* (Assigns "Porthos" to item) */

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the array contains an item associated with the specified index or indexes. Returns &false; otherwise.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples hasIndex method
Array class — hasIndex method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred", "Rick") say a~hasIndex(2) -- says: 1 say a~hasIndex(5) -- says: 0

section.title: hasItem
section.para:
Returns &true; if the array contains the specified item at any index location. Returns &false; otherwise. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item. examples hasItem method
Array class — hasItem method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred", "Rick") say a~hasItem("Rick") -- says: 1 say a~hasItem("Mark") -- says: 0

section.title: index
section.para:
Returns the index of the specified item within the array. If the target item appears at more than one index, the first located index will be returned. For &multidimarray;s, the index is returned as an array of index values. If the array does not contain the specified item, &nil; is returned. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item. examples index method
Array class — index method
a = .array~of("Mike", "Rick", "Fred", "Rick") say a~index("Rick") -- says: 2

section.title: insert
section.para: Returns an Array-supplied index for item item, which is added to the Array. The inserted item follows an existing item with index index in the Array ordering. If index is &nil;, item becomes the first item in the Array. If you omit index, the item becomes the last item in the Array.

Inserting an item in the Array at position index will cause the items in the Array after position index to have their indexes shifted by the Array object. The index values for any items in the Array are incremented by the insertion. examples insert method of Array class
Array class — insert method
musketeers=.Array~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis") /* Creates Array MUSKETEERS */ /* consisting of: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",1) /* Adds D'Artagnan after Porthos */ /* Array is now: Porthos */ /* D'Artagnan */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",.nil) /* Adds D'Artagnan before Porthos */ /* Array is now: D'Artagnan */ /* Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan") /* Adds D'Artagnan after Aramis */ /* Array is now: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* D'Artagnan */

section.title: isEmpty
section.para:
Returns &true; if the array is empty. Returns &false; otherwise. examples isEmpty method
Array class — isEmpty method
a = .array~new say a~isEmpty -- says: 1 a[1] = "1" say a~isEmpty -- says: 0

section.title: items
section.para:
Returns the number of items in the array. examples items method
Array class — items method
a = .array~of("Fred", , "Mike", , "David") say a~items -- says: 3

section.title: last
section.para:
Returns the index of the last item in the array or &nil; if the array is empty. For &multidimarray;s, index is returned as an array of index items. examples last method
Array class — last method
a = .array~of("Fred", , "Mike", , "David") say a~last -- says: 5

section.title: lastItem
section.para:
Returns the last item in the array or &nil; if the array is empty.
Array class — lastItem method
musketeers=.array~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis"") /* Creates array MUSKETEERS */ item=musketeers~lastItem /* Gives last item in array */ /* (Assigns "Aramis" to item) */

section.title: makeArray
section.para:
Returns a &singledimarray; with the same number of items as the receiver object. Any index with no associated item is omitted from the new array. Items in the new array will have the same order as the source array. A &multidimarray; will be converted into a non-sparse &singledimarray;. examples makeArray method
Array class — makeArray method
a = .array~of("Fred", , "Mike", , "David") b = a~makeArray -- b = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "David")

section.title: makeString
section.para: Returns a string that contains the data of an array (one to n dimensional). The elements of the array are treated either in line or character format, starting at the first element in the array. The line format is the default. If the line format is used, a separator string can be specified. The separator will be used between concatenated elements instead of the default line end separator.
See method (which is a synonym for this method) for examples.

section.title: next
section.para: Returns the index of the item that follows the array item having index index or returns &nil; if the item having that index is last in the array. For &multidimarray;s, the same ordering as used by the method is used to determine the next position and the index is returned as an array of index values.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples next method
Array class — next method
a = .array~of("Fred", , "Mike", , "David") say a~next(3) -- says: 5

section.title: previous
section.para: Returns the index of the item that precedes the array item having index index or &nil; if the item having that index is first in the array. For &multidimarray;s, the same ordering used by the method is used to determine the previous position and the index is returned as an array of index values.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples previous method
Array class — previous method
a = .array~of("Fred", , "Mike", , "David") say a~previous(3) -- says: 1

section.title: put
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the array and associates it with the specified index or indexes. This replaces any existing item associated with the specified index or indexes with the new item. If the index for a particular dimension is greater than the current size of that dimension, the array is expanded to the new dimension size.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples put method
Array class — put method
a = .array~new a~put("Fred", 1) -- a = .array~of("Fred") a~put("Mike", 2) -- a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike") a~put("Mike", 1) -- a = .array~of("Mike", "Mike")
do name over a say name end
/* Output would be: */
Mike Mike

section.title: remove
section.para: Returns and removes the member item with the specified index or indexes from the array. If there is no item with the specified index or indexes, &nil; is returned and no item is removed. The index of the removed item becomes unused and the hasIndex method for the given index will now return &false;. The size of the array is unchanged and no other indexes of the array are modified with the removal.

Note that the index argument may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples remove method
Array class — remove method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "Mike", "David") a~remove(2) -- removes "Mike"

section.title: removeItem
section.para:
Removes an item from the array. If the target item exists at more than one index, the first located item is removed. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item. The return value is the removed item. examples removeItem method
Array class — removeItem method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "Mike", "David") a~removeItem("Mike") -- removes the item at index "2"

section.title: section
section.para: Returns a new array (of the same class as the receiver) containing selected items from the receiver array. The first item in the new array is the item corresponding to index start in the receiver array. Subsequent items in the new array correspond to those in the receiver array (in the same sequence). If you specify the whole number items, the new array contains only this number of items (or the number of subsequent items in the receiver array, if this is less than items). If you do not specify items, the new array contains all subsequent items of the receiver array. The receiver array remains unchanged. The section method is valid only for &singledimarray;s.

Note that the index argument start may also be specified as an array of indexes. examples section method
Array class — section method
a = .array~of(1,2,3,4) -- Loads the array
b = a~section(2) -- b = .array~of(2,3,4) c = a~section(2,2) -- c = .array~of(2,3) d = a~section(2,0) -- d = .array~new

section.title: size
section.para: Returns the number of items that can be placed in the array before it needs to be extended. This value is the same as the product of the sizes of the dimensions in the array.

section.title: sort
section.para: Sorts the Array of Comparable items into ascending order using an algorithm that is not guaranteed to be stable, and returns the sorted Array. See for details.

section.title: sortWith
section.para: Sorts the Array of items into ascending order using an algorithm that is not guaranteed to be stable, and returns the sorted Array. Ordering of elements is determined using the comparator argument. See for details.

section.title: stableSort
section.para: Sorts the Array of Comparable items into ascending order using a stable Mergesort algorithm, and returns the sorted Array. See for details.

section.title: stableSortWith
section.para: Sorts the Array of items into ascending order using a stable Mergesort algorithm, and returns the sorted Array. Ordering of elements is determined using the comparator argument. See for details.

section.title: supplier
section.para:
Returns a object for the array. The supplier allows you to iterate over the index/item pairs of the array. The supplier enumerates the array items in their sequenced order. For &multidimarray;s, the supplier index method will return the index values as an array of index numbers. examples supplier method
Array class — supplier method
a = .array~of("Fred", "Mike", "David") sup = a~supplier a~append("Joe") do while sup~available say sup~item -- displays "Fred", "Mike", and "David" sup~next end

section.title: toString
section.para: Returns a string that contains the data of an array (one to n dimensional). The elements of the array are treated either in line or character format, starting at the first element in the array. The line format is the default. If the line format is used, a separator string can be specified. The separator will be used between concatenated elements instead of the default line end separator.

See also method for which this method is a synonym. examples toString method
Array class — toString method
a = .array~of(1,2,3,4) -- Loads the array
say a~toString -- Produces: 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4
say a~toString("c") -- Produces: 1234
say a~toString(, ", ") -- Produces: 1, 2, 3, 4

section.title: Examples

example.title: Array class — examples
example.programlisting:
array1=.array~of(1,2,3,4) /* Loads the array */
/* Alternative way to create and load an array */ array2=.array~new(4) /* Creates array2, containing 4 items */ do i=1 to 4 /* Loads the array */ array2[i]=i end

section.para:
You can produce the elements loaded into an array, for example:
Array class — examples
do i=1 to 4 say array1[i] end

If you omit any argument values before arguments you supply, the corresponding indexes are skipped in the returned array:
Array class — examples
directions=.array~of("North","South", ,"West") do i=1 to 4 /* Produces: North */ say directions[i] /* South */ /* The NIL object */ end /* West */

Here is an example using the ~~:
Array class — examples
z=.array~of(1,2,3)~~put(4,4) do i = 1 to z~size say z[i] /* Produces: 1 2 3 4 */ end

section.title: Bag Class
section.para: A Bag is a non-sparse collection that restricts the elements to having an item that is the same as the index. Any object can be placed in a Bag, and the same object can be placed in a Bag several times.

section.title: &changed50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new empty Bag object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new Bag object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.

section.title: of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created Bag containing the specified item objects.
Returns the item associated with index index. Returns &nil; if the Bag has no item associated with index.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.
This method is the same as the method.

section.title: allAt
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing all the items associated with index index.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.
This method has the same result as the method.

section.title: allIndex
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing all indexes for item item.
Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.
This method has the same result as the method.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an Array of all indexes contained in the Bag, in an unspecified order. The returned Array will have one index for every item stored in the Bag, including duplicates.
To retrieve the indexes without duplicates, use the method.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an Array of all items contained in the Bag, in an unspecified order.

section.title: at
section.para: Returns the item associated with index index. Returns &nil; if the Bag does not contain index.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.
This method is the same as the method.
Adds an item to the Bag. index and item must be the same object.
This method is the same as the method.

section.title: difference
section.para: Returns a new Bag containing only those items from the receiver that the argument collection does not contain. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: empty
section.para: Returns the receiving Bag with all items removed.

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the Bag contains any item associated with index index, otherwise returns &false;.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the Bag contains the member item item, otherwise returns &false;. If index is specified, it should be the same object as index, otherwise hasItem will always return &false;.
Item and index equality is determined by using the == method.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index for item item if the Bag contains item, otherwise returns &false;.
Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: intersection
section.para: Returns a new Bag containing only those items from the receiver that are also in the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: isEmpty
section.para: Returns &true; if the Bag is empty. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of Bag items with index index. If you specify no index, this method returns the total number of items in the Bag.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing all Bag items, in an unspecified order.

section.title: put
section.para: Adds an item to the Bag. If specified, index must be the same object as item.
This method is the same as the method.

section.title: putAll
section.para: Returns the receiving Bag with all items in collection added to it. The collection argument can be any object that supports a supplier method. Items from collection are added using the item values returned by the supplier.

section.title: remove
section.para: Returns and removes from the Bag one member item with index index. Returns &nil; if the Bag does not contain index.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.

section.title: removeAll
section.para: Returns and removes from the Bag all member items with index index. All removed items are returned in an Array containing each of the removed items. If the Bag does not contain index, an empty Array is returned.
Index equality is determined by using the == method of index.

section.title: removeItem
section.para: Returns and removes from a Bag one member item item. Returns &nil; if item is not a member of the Bag.
If index is specified, it should be the same object as index, otherwise removeItem will always return &nil;.

section.title: subset
section.para: Returns &true; if all indexes in the receiver Bag are also contained in the argument collection; returns &false; otherwise. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the Bag. The supplier allows you to iterate over all index/item pairs in the Bag at the time the supplier was created. The supplier enumerates the items in an unspecified order. If you specify index, the supplier contains all of the items with the specified index.

section.title: union
section.para: Returns a new Bag that contains all the items from the receiver Bag and selected items from the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: uniqueIndexes
section.para: Returns an Array of all indexes contained in the Bag, with no duplicates.

section.title: xor
section.para: Returns a new Bag that contains all items from the receiver Bag and the argument collection; items that appear in both collections are removed. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

example.title: Bag class — examples
example.programlisting: /* Create a bag of fruit */ fruit = .bag~of("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear") say fruit~items /* How many pieces? (4) */ say fruit~items("Apple") /* How many apples? (2) */ fruit~remove("Apple") /* Remove one of the apples. */ fruit~~put("Banana")~put("Orange") /* Add a couple. */ say fruit~items /* How many pieces? (5) */

section.title: CircularQueue Class
section.para: The CircularQueue class allows for storing objects in a circular queue of a predefined size. Once the end of the queue has been reached, new item objects are inserted from the beginning, replacing earlier entries. Any object can be placed in the queue and the same object can occupy more than one position in the queue.
The collected objects can be processed in FIFO (first-in, first-out) or in a stack-like LIFO (last-in, first-out) order.

section.title: of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created circular queue containing the specified item objects. The first item has index 1, the second has index 2, and so on. Any omitted item will be set to the null string. The total number of item objects (including omitted ones) determines the size of the circular queue.

section.title: init
section.para: Performs initialization of the circular queue. The required size argument, a non-negative whole number, specifies the initial size of the queue.

section.title: append
section.para: Append an item to the end of the collection ordering, returning the index of the added item. If the circular queue is full, then the first item will be deleted, before the insertion takes place.

section.title: insert
section.para: Returns a queue-supplied index for item, which is added to the queue. The inserted item follows any existing item with index index in the queue ordering. If index is &nil;, item is inserted at the head of the queue. If you omit index, item becomes the last item in the queue.

Inserting an item in the queue at position index will cause the items in the queue after position index to have their indexes modified by the queue object. If inserting an object causes the queue to grow beyond the size, the last item in the queue will be removed.

section.title: intersection
section.para: Returns a new collection (of the same class as the receiver) containing only those items from the receiver that are in both the receiver collection and the argument collection. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;. The resulting CircularQueue instance will be the same size as the receiver.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing the items of the circular queue in the specified order.
The following order can be used. (Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored.)

listitem.para: First-in, first-out order. This is the default.
Last-in, first-out order (stack-like).

section.title: &added50;makeString
section.para: Returns a string object that concatenates the string values of the collected item objects, using the delimiter string to delimit them, in the specified order. If the delimiter is omitted, the comma character (",") is used as the default delimiter string.
The following order can be used. (Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored.)

listitem.para: First-in, first-out. This is the default
Last-in, first-out (stack-like)

example.title: CircularQueue class — makeArray method examplesmakeArray method
example.programlisting: -- reverse an array a = .Array~of("one", "two", "three", "four", "five") say .CircularQueue~new(a~size)~appendAll(a)~makeArray("lifo")~makeString(, ", ") -- five, four, three, two, one

section.title: push
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the circular queue, inserting the item object in front of the first item in the queue. The pushed item object will be the new first item in the circular queue.

If the circular queue is full, then the last item stored in the circular queue will be deleted, before the insertion takes place. In this case the deleted item will be returned, otherwise &nil; will be returned.

If option is specified, it may be "Normal" or "Unique". The default is "Normal". Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored. If option is 'Unique', any matching items already in the queue will be removed before item is added to the queue. This allows you to maintain a list like the recent files list of an editor.

section.title: queue
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the circular queue, inserting the item at the end of the circular queue.
If the circular queue is full, then the first item will be deleted, before the insertion takes place. In this case the deleted item will be returned, otherwise &nil; will be returned.

If option is specified, it may be "Normal" or "Unique". The default is "Normal". Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored. If option is 'Unique', any matching items already in the queue will be removed before item is added to the queue. This allows you to maintain a list like the recent files list of an editor.

section.title: resize
section.para: Resizes the circular queue object to be able to contain newSize items. If more than newSize items are in the queue, any extra items are removed in the specified order.
The following order can be used. (Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored.)

listitem.para: First-in, first-out. This keeps the items at the front of the queue. Item deletions occur at the end of the queue. This is the default action.
Last-in, first-out (stack-like). This removes items from the front of the queue.

note.title: Note:
note.para: Resizing with a value of 0 removes all items from the circular queue.

section.title: section
section.para: Returns a new queue (of the same class as the receiver) containing selected items from the receiver. The first item in the new queue is the item corresponding to index start in the receiver. Subsequent items in the new queue correspond to those in the receiver (in the same sequence). If you specify the whole number items, the new queue contains only this number of items (or the number of subsequent items in the receiver, if this is less than items). If you do not specify items, the new queue contains all subsequent items from the receiver. The receiver queue remains unchanged. The new queue item will be sized to the larger of the receiver queue size or items. The selection of the items will wrap from the end around to the beginning of the queue. For example,
section.programlisting:
q1 = .circularqueue~of("Fred", "Mike", "David") q2 = q1~section(2) -- effectively rotates the queue
do name over a say name -- displays "Mike", "David", and "Fred" end
section.para: returns a new queue of three items, starting with the second item, effectively rotating the order of the contained items.

section.title: size
section.para: Returns the maximum number of objects that can be stored in the circular queue.

section.title: string
section.para: Returns a string object that concatenates the string values of the collected item objects, using the delimiter string to delimit them, in the specified order. If the delimiter is omitted, the comma character (",") is used as the default delimiter string.
The following order can be used. (Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored.)

listitem.para: First-in, first-out. This is the default
Last-in, first-out (stack-like)

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the collection. The supplier allows you to iterate over the items that were in the queue at the time of the supplier's creation.
The supplier will iterate over the items in the specified order. (Only the capitalized letter is needed; all characters following it are ignored.)

listitem.para: First-in, first-out, default
Last-in, first-out (stack-like)

section.title: union
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all the items from the receiver collection and selected items from the argument collection. The resulting CircularQueue object will have a size that is the larger of the receiver's size or the union size of the two collections. This method includes an item from argument in the new collection only if there is no equivalent item in the receiver collection and the method has not already included. The order in which this method selects items in argument is unspecified (the program should not rely on any order.). The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

section.title: xor
section.para: Returns a new collection of the same class as the receiver that contains all items from the receiver collection and the argument collection; all items that appear in both collections are removed. The resulting CircularQueue object will have a size that is the larger of the receiver's size or the xor size of the two collections. The argument can be &collection_or_makearray;.

example.title: CircularQueue class — examples
example.programlisting:
-- create a circular buffer with five items u=.circularQueue~of("a", "b", "c", "d", "e") say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say
u~resize(4, "FIFO") -- resize fifo-style (keep newest) say "after resizing to 4 items in FIFO style (keeping the newest):" say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say
u~resize(2, "LIFO") -- resize lifo-style (keep oldest) say "after resizing to 2 items in LIFO style (keeping the oldest):" say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say
u~resize(0) -- resize lifo-style (keep oldest) say "after resizing to 0 items, thereby deleting all items:" say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say
u~resize(2) -- resize lifo-style (keep oldest) say "after resizing to 2, size="u~size "and items="u~items u~~queue('x')~~queue('y')~~queue('z') say "after queuing the three items 'x', 'y', 'z':" say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say
u~~push('1')~~push('2')~~push('3') say "after pushing the three items '1', '2', '3':" say "content: ["u"]," "content (LIFO): ["u~string("->","L")"]" say

content: [a,b,c,d,e], content (LIFO): [e->d->c->b->a]
after resizing to 4 items in FIFO style (keeping the newest): content: [b,c,d,e], content (LIFO): [e->d->c->b]
after resizing to 2 items in LIFO style (keeping the oldest): content: [b,c], content (LIFO): [c->b]
after resizing to 0 items, thereby deleting all items: content: [], content (LIFO): []
after resizing to 2, size=2 and items=0 after queuing the three items 'x', 'y', 'z': content: [y,z], content (LIFO): [z->y]
after pushing the three items '1', '2', '3': content: [3,2], content (LIFO): [2->3]

section.title: Directory Class
section.para:
A Directory is a
using unique character string indexes. The items of a Directory can be any valid Rexx object.
See also , a MapCollection similar to Directory, but without methods setMethod and unsetMethod.

In addition to the standard put, []=, at, and [] methods defined for Collections, Directory provides access to items using methods. For example:
mydir = .directory~new mydir~name = "Mike" -- same as mydir~put("Mike", "NAME") say mydir~name -- same as say mydir['NAME']

section.title: &changed50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns an empty Directory object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new Directory object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.
Returns the item corresponding to name. This method is the same as the method.
Adds or replaces the entry at index name. This method is the same as the method.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an array of all the directory indexes, including those of all the methods.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an array of all items contained in the directory, including those returned by all methods.

section.title: at
section.para:
Returns the item associated with index name. If a method defined using is associated with index name, the result of running this method is returned. If the Directory has no item or method associated with index name, &nil; is returned.
Directory class — at method
say .environment~at("OBJECT") /* Produces: "The Object class" */

section.title: empty
section.para: Returns the receiving Directory with all items removed. empty also removes all methods added using .

section.title: entry
section.para: Returns the directory entry with index name (translated to uppercase). If there is no such entry, name returns the item for any method that supplied. If there is neither an entry nor a method for name, &nil; is returned.

section.title: hasEntry
section.para: Returns &true; if the directory has an entry or a method for index name (translated to uppercase), or &false;.

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the Directory contains any item associated with index name, or &false;.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the Directory contains the item at any index position or otherwise returns &false;. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the specified item within the directory. If the target item appears at more than one index, the first located index will be returned. If the directory does not contain the specified item, &nil; is returned. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: isEmpty
section.para: Returns &true; if the directory is empty. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of items in the collection.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing the index objects. The array indexes range from 1 to the number of items. The collection items appear in the array in an unspecified order. (The program should not rely on any order.)

section.title: put
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the collection and associates it with index name. The new item replaces any existing item or method associated with index name.

section.title: remove
section.para: Removes and returns the member item with index name from the directory. If a method is associated with for index name, the method is removed and the result of running the method is returned. If there is no item or method with index name, &nil; is returned.

section.title: &added50;removeEntry
section.para: Removes and returns the member item with index name (translated to uppercase) from the directory. If a method is associated with for index name, the method is removed and the result of running the method is returned. If there is no item or method with index name, &nil; is returned.
See also , , , and .

section.title: removeItem
section.para: Removes an item from the directory. If the target item exists at more than one index, the first located item is removed. The return value is the removed item. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: setEntry
section.para: Sets the directory entry with index name (translated to uppercase) to the object entry, replacing any existing entry or method for name. If you omit entry, this method removes any entry or method with this name.

section.title: setMethod
section.para: Associates index name (translated to uppercase) with method method. Thus, the object returns the result of running method when you access this entry. This occurs when you specify name on the at, entry, or remove method. This method replaces any existing item or method for name.

You can specify "UNKNOWN" as name. Doing so supplies a method that is run whenever an at or entry message specifies a name for which no item or method exists in the collection. This method's first argument is the specified directory index. This method has no effect on the action of any hasEntry, hasIndex, items, remove, or supplier message sent to the collection.

The method can be a string containing a method source line instead of a method object. Alternatively, an array of strings containing individual method lines can be passed. In either case, an equivalent method object is created.
If you omit method, setMethod removes the entry with the specified name.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the collection. The supplier allows you to iterate over the index/item pairs in the directory at the time the supplier was created. The supplier iterates the items in an unspecified order.

section.title: unknown
section.para: Runs either the or method, depending on whether messagename ends with an equal sign.
If messagename does not end with an equal sign, this method runs the entry method, passing messagename as its argument. The messageargs argument is ignored. The entry method is the return result.

If messagename does end with an equal sign, this method runs the setEntry method, passing the first part of messagename (up to, but not including, the final equal sign) as its first argument, and the first item in the array messageargs as its second argument. In this case, unknown returns no result.

section.title: unsetMethod
section.para: Removes the association between index name (translated to uppercase) and a method.

example.title: Directory class — examples

section.title: IdentityTable Class
section.para: An IdentityTable is a collection with indexes that can be any object. In an IdentityTable, each item is associated with a single index, and there can be only one item for each index. Index and item matches are made using an object identity comparison. That is, an index will only match if the same instance is used in the collection.

section.title: &changed50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns an empty IdentityTable object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new IdentityTable object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.
Returns the item associated with index. This method is the same as the method.
Adds item to the table at index index. This method is the same as the method.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an array of all indices contained in the table.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an array of all items contained in the table.

section.title: at
section.para: Returns the item associated with index index. Returns &nil; if the IdentityTable has no item associated with index.

section.title: empty
section.para: Returns the receiving IdentityTable with all items removed.

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the IdentityTable contains any item associated with index index, or &false;.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the IdentityTable contains the item at any index position or otherwise returns &false;.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the specified item within the table. If the target item appears at more than one index, the first located index will be returned. Returns &nil; if the table does not contain the specified item.

section.title: isEmpty
section.para: Returns &true; if the table is empty. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of items in the collection.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing the index objects. The array indexes range from 1 to the number of items. The collection items appear in the array in an unspecified order.

section.title: put
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the collection and associates it with index index. The new item replaces any existing item associated with index index.

section.title: remove
section.para: Returns and removes from a collection the member item with index index. Returns &nil; if no item has index index.

section.title: removeItem
section.para: Removes an item from the table. If the target item exists at more than one index, the first located item is removed. The return value is the removed item.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the collection. The supplier allows you iterate over the index/item pairs contained in the table at the time the supplier was created. The supplier iterates over the items in an unspecified order.

section.title: List Class
section.para: A List is a non-sparse sequenced collection similar to the to which you can add new items at any position in the sequence. The List creates a new index value whenever an item is added to the List and the associated index value remains valid for that item regardless of other additions or removals. Only indexes the List object generates are valid, i.e. the List is never a sparse list and the List object will not modify indexes for items in the list.

section.title: &changed50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new empty List object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new List object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.

section.title: of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created list containing the specified item objects in the order specified.
Returns the item located at index. This method is the same as the .
Replaces the item at index with item. This method is the same as the .

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an array of all indexes contained in the list in the same order they are used in the list.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an array of all items contained in the list in list iteration order.

section.title: append
section.para: Appends item to the end of the list, returning the index associated with item.

section.title: at
section.para: Returns the item associated with index index. Returns &nil; if the list has no item associated with index.

section.title: delete
section.para: Returns and deletes the member item with the specified index from the list. If there is no item with the specified index, &nil; is returned and no item is deleted. All elements following the deleted item will be moved up in the list ordering, but the indexes associated with the moved items will not change. The size of the list will be reduced by one element. The delete method and the remove method produce the same result for the list class.

section.title: empty
section.para: Returns the receiving List with all items removed.

section.title: first
section.para: Returns the index of the first item in the list or &nil; if the list is empty.

section.title: firstItem
section.para:
Returns the first item in the list or &nil; if the list is empty.
List class — firstItem method
musketeers=.list~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis") /* Creates list MUSKETEERS */ item=musketeers~firstItem /* Gives first item in list */ /* (Assigns "Porthos" to item) */

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the list contains any item associated with index index, or &false;.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the list contains the item at any index position or otherwise returns &false;. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the specified item within the list. If the target item appears at more than one index, the first located index will be returned. Returns &nil; if the list does not contain the specified item. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: insert
section.para: Returns a list-supplied index for item item, which is added to the list. The inserted item follows an existing item with index index in the list ordering. If index is &nil;, item becomes the first item in the list. If you omit index, the item becomes the last item in the list.

Inserting an item in the list at position index will cause the items in the list after position index to have their relative positions shifted by the list object. The index values for any items in the list are not modified by the insertion. examples insert method of List class
List class — insert method
musketeers=.list~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis") /* Creates list MUSKETEERS */ /* consisting of: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ index=musketeers~first /* Gives index of first item */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",index) /* Adds D'Artagnan after Porthos */ /* List is now: Porthos */ /* D'Artagnan */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",.nil) /* Adds D'Artagnan before Porthos */ /* List is now: D'Artagnan */ /* Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan") /* Adds D'Artagnan after Aramis */ /* List is now: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* D'Artagnan */

section.title: isEmpty
section.para: Returns &true; if the list is empty. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of items in the list.

section.title: last
section.para: Returns the index of the last item in the list or &nil; if the list is empty.

section.title: lastItem
section.para: Returns the last item in the list or &nil; if the list is empty.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing the list collection items. The array indexes range from 1 to the number of items. The order in which the collection items appear in the array is the same as their sequence in the list collection.

section.title: next
section.para: Returns the index of the item that follows the list item having index index. Returns &nil; if index is the end of the list.

section.title: previous
section.para: Returns the index of the item that precedes the list item having index index. Returns &nil; if index is the beginning of the list.

section.title: put
section.para: Replaces any existing item associated with the specified index with the item. If index does not exist in the list, an error is raised.

section.title: remove
section.para: Returns and removes from a collection the member item with index index. If no item has index index, this method returns &nil; and removes no item.
Removing an item from the list at position index will shift the relative position of items after position index. The index values assigned to those items will not change.

section.title: removeItem
section.para: Removes an item from the list. If the target item exists at more than one index, the first located item is removed. The return value is the removed item. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: section
section.para: Returns a new list (of the same class as the receiver) containing selected items from the receiver list. The first item in the new list is the item corresponding to index start in the receiver list. Subsequent items in the new list correspond to those in the receiver list (in the same sequence). If you specify the whole number items, the new list contains only this number of items (or the number of subsequent items in the receiver list, if this is less than items). If you do not specify items, the new list contains all subsequent items from the receiver list. The receiver list remains unchanged.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the list. The supplier allows you to iterate over the index/item pairs stored in the list at the time the supplier is created. The iteration is in the same order as the list sequence order.

section.title: Properties Class
section.para: A Properties object is a collection with unique indexes that are character strings representing names and items that are also restricted to character string values. Properties objects are useful for processing bundles of application option values.

section.title: load (Class method)
section.para: Loads a set of properties from source and returns them as a new Properties object. The load source can be either the string name of a file, a File object, or a Stream object. Properties are read from source as individual lines using . Blank lines and lines with a Rexx line comment ("--") as the first non-blank characters are ignored. Otherwise, the lines are assumed to be of the form "name=value" and are added to the receiver Properties value using name as the index for the value.

section.title: &changed50;new (Class method)
section.para: Returns an empty Properties object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new Properties object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.
Adds item using the index index. This method is the same as the method.

section.title: getLogical
section.para: Returns the value of name as either &true; or &false;. The raw value of the name may be either the numeric values "0" or "1" or the string values "true" or "false". Any other value will raise a syntax error. If the property name does not exist and default has been specified, the default value will be returned. If default has not been specified, a syntax error is raised for missing values.

section.title: getProperty
section.para: Returns the value of name. If property name does not exist and default has been specified, the default value will be returned. If default has not been specified, &nil; is returned.

section.title: getWhole
section.para: Returns the value of name, validated as being a Rexx whole number. If property name does not exist and default has been specified, the default value will be returned. If default has not been specified, a syntax error is raised for missing values.

section.title: load
section.para: Loads a set of properties into the receiving Properties object from source. The load source can be either the string name of a file, a File object, or a Stream object. Properties are read from the source as individual lines using . Blank lines and lines with a Rexx line comment ("--") as the first non-blank characters are ignored. Otherwise, the lines are assumed to be of the form "name=value" and are added to the receiver Properties value using name as the index for the value.
Properties loaded from source that have the same names as existing items will replace the current entries.

section.title: put
section.para: Makes the object item a member item of the collection and associates it with index name. The item value must be a character string. The new item replaces any existing item or method associated with index name.

section.title: save
section.para: Saves a set of properties into target. The save target can be either the string name of a file, a File object, or a Stream object. Properties are stored as individual lines using . The lines are written in the form "name=value". A saved Properties file can be reloaded using the Properties method.

section.title: setLogical
section.para: Sets a logical value in the property bundle. The value argument must be either the numbers "0" or "1", or the logical values &true; or &false;. The property value will be added with value converted in to the appropriate "true" or "false" string value.

section.title: setProperty
section.para: Sets a named property in the property bundle. The value argument must be a character string value.

section.title: setWhole
section.para: Sets a whole number value in the property bundle. The value argument must be a valid Rexx whole number.

section.title: Queue Class
section.para: A Queue is a non-sparse sequenced collection with whole-number indexes. The indexes specify the position of an item relative to the head (first item) of the queue. Adding or removing an item changes the association of an index to its queue item. You can add items at either the tail or the head of the queue.

section.title: &changed50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new empty Queue object.
If you specify size, a hint how large the new Queue object is expected to grow, this is used to optimize the initial allocation.
size must be a non-negative whole number.

section.title: of (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a newly created queue containing the specified item objects in the order specified.
Returns the item located at index index. This method is the same as the method.
Replaces item at index with item. This method is the same as the method.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an array of all index values for the queue.
For the Queue class, the indices are integers 1 - items.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an array of all items contained in the queue, in queue order.

section.title: append
section.para: Appends item to the end of the queue, returning the index of the inserted item.

section.title: at
section.para: Returns the item associated with index index. Returns &nil; if the Queue has no item associated with index.

section.title: delete
section.para:
Returns and deletes the member item with the specified index from the queue. If there is no item with the specified index, &nil; is returned and no item is deleted. All elements following the deleted item will be moved up in the queue ordering and the item indexes will be adjusted for the deletion. The size of the queue will be reduced by one element. The delete method and the remove method produce the same result for the queue class. examples delete method
Queue class — delete method
a = .queue~of("Fred", "Mike", "Rick", "David") a~delete(2) -- removes "Mike", resulting in the queue -- ("Fred", "Rick", "David")

section.title: empty
section.para: Returns the receiving Queue with all items removed.

section.title: first
section.para: Returns the index of the first item in the queue or &nil; if the queue is empty. The index will always be 1 for non-empty queues.

section.title: firstItem
section.para: Returns the first item in the queue or &nil; if the queue is empty.

section.title: hasIndex
section.para: Returns &true; if the queue contains any item associated with index index, or &false;.

section.title: hasItem
section.para: Returns &true; if the queue contains the item at any index position or otherwise returns &false;. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the specified item within the queue. If the target item appears at more than one index, the first located index will be returned. Returns &nil; if the queue does not contain the specified item. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: insert
section.para: Returns a queue-supplied index for item, which is added to the queue. The inserted item follows any existing item with index index in the queue ordering. If index is &nil;, item is inserted at the head of the queue. If you omit index, item becomes the last item in the queue.

Inserting an item in the queue at position index will cause the items in the queue after position index to have their indexes modified by the queue object. examples insert method of Queue class
Queue class — insert method
musketeers=.queue~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis) /* Creates queue MUSKETEERS */ /* consisting of: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ index=musketeers~first /* Gives index of first item */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",index) /* Adds D'Artagnan after Porthos */ /* List is now: Porthos */ /* D'Artagnan */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan",.nil) /* Adds D'Artagnan before Porthos */ /* List is now: D'Artagnan */ /* Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* Alternately, you could use */ musketeers~insert("D'Artagnan") /* Adds D'Artagnan after Aramis */ /* List is now: Porthos */ /* Athos */ /* Aramis */ /* D'Artagnan */

section.title: isEmpty
section.para: Returns &true; if the queue is empty. Returns &false; otherwise.

section.title: items
section.para: Returns the number of items in the collection.

section.title: last
section.para: Returns the index of the last item in the queue or &nil; if the queue is empty.

section.title: lastItem
section.para:
Returns the last item in the array or &nil; if the array is empty.
Queue class — lastItem method
musketeers=.array~of("Porthos","Athos","Aramis"") /* Creates array MUSKETEERS */ item=musketeers~lastItem /* Gives last item in array */ /* (Assigns "Aramis" to item) */

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a &singledimarray; containing the receiver queue items. The array indexes range from 1 to the number of items. The order in which the queue items appear in the array is the same as their queuing order, with the head of the queue as index 1.

section.title: next
section.para: Returns the index of the item that follows the queue item having index index or returns &nil; if the item having that index is last in the queue.

section.title: peek
section.para: Returns the item at the head of the queue. Returns &nil; if the queue is empty. The collection remains unchanged.

section.title: previous
section.para: Returns the index of the item that precedes the queue item having index index or &nil; if the item having that index is first in the queue.

section.title: pull
section.para: Returns and removes the item at the head of the queue. Returns &nil; if the queue is empty.

section.title: push
section.para: Adds the object item to the head of the queue.

section.title: put
section.para: Replaces any existing item associated with the specified index with the new item. If the index does not exist in the queue, an error is raised.

section.title: queue
section.para: Adds the object item to the tail of the queue.

section.title: remove
section.para: Returns and removes from a collection the member item with index index. Returns &nil; if no item has index index.

section.title: removeItem
section.para: Removes an item from the queue. If the target item exists at more than one index, the first located item is removed. The return value is the removed item. Item equality is determined by using the == method of item.

section.title: section
section.para: Returns a new queue (of the same class as the receiver) containing selected items from the receiver. The first item in the new queue is the item corresponding to index start in the receiver. Subsequent items in the new queue correspond to those in the receiver (in the same sequence). If you specify the whole number items, the new queue contains only this number of items (or the number of subsequent items in the receiver, if this is less than items). If you do not specify items, the new queue contains all subsequent items from the receiver. The receiver queue remains unchanged.

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns a object for the queue. The supplier allows you to iterate over the index/item pair contained in the queue at the time the supplier was created. The supplier iterates the items in their queuing order, with the head of the queue first.
